title: Closing Bell: Fastenal Rises, Warner Bros Climbs, Waters Declines | Stock Movers

rawLines.text: [Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
This is the closing bell on the stock
movers report. The company's making
moves at the close of US trading with
Carol Masser, Tim Stenc, Roma Bostic,
and Scarlett Fu.
All right, on the gainer side, a new
all-time high for Fasinel. The company
reported earnings earlier today. shares
4% higher at the close. The company
reported net sales for the second
quarter that were up 8.6% over the same
period last year. It did meet the
average analyst estimate. We had Dan
Flores on the show, the company's CEO.
He said that his industrial customers
are starting to see business turnaround.
Here's what he said. Quote, "The knife
has stopped dropping." What he was
referring to is the trying to catch a
falling knife over the last few years
that really in the US has been
industrial production. I did ask him and
Norah asked him too about the impact of
tariffs and he said they tried to move
their supply chain back in 2018 during
this first round and they were able to
make some changes not necessarily
bringing anything back to the US just
not possible right now. Uh too early to
say for his customers though whether
this new tariff regime will prompt them
to move manufacturing back to the US.
It's just a reminder of how long it
takes to actually move your supply chain
back to the US. They were talking about
this back in 2017 and, you know, weren't
able to to get very far.
Yeah. I mean, do you remember the move
back in 2017 and 2018 was to move
everything out of China and like go to
Vietnam or Indonesia or India? Well, now
it kind of doesn't matter where you are
if you're not in the United States
because all of those countries are
getting tariffed as well. Hey, did any
of you guys see Superman over the
weekend?
No. Was it good?
I didn't see it either. A lot of people
did see it though.
We look at you when we see Superman. I
was going to say,
wow, you guys, you guys are the best. Uh
Warner Brothers Discovery shares up more
than 2%. Uh this after the company did
say uh that they brought in at least
$115 million domestically. It did take
in $220 million worldwide. This
according to a statement from Warner
Brothers, excuse me, $125 million in
ticket sales in the US. So that did beat
expectations of $115 million. This is
just the opening chapter in a 10-year
plan dinner weave movies and TV shows
based on DC comic book characters such
as Batman and Wonder Woman. Would
haven't they done this before?
Yeah.
Okay. All right. I'm just
They've done this. So, I mean, I don't
know. Do you think DC is going to get it
right this time? I mean, everyone's
saying, "Okay, you had a decent box
office domestically, though, don't look
at the international numbers, Tim. Was
not as good." But this idea that maybe
they could finally build off this and
and actually truly build up something
that's comparable to the Marvel
universe. Look, I don't know what it
takes to have a successful franchise.
No,
I don't either, but I like but but we
can we can look and see what you know
what what the Marvel universe has done,
right?
Peanut gallery speaks.
Yeah, exactly. I think James Gunn knows
a little more than we do when it comes
to what makes a successful movie. Uh and
finally, I I do want to talk about Shen
View real quick. Up they finished the
day higher today by more than 2%. It's
the company behind Tylenol, Neutrogena
Listister, formerly the consumer
healthcare division of J&J. The company
said that CEO Thiba Ming Mongol is going
to leave the company as it continues to
revamp. The board director Kirk Perry
will take over as interim CEO effective
immediately. They faced push from
activist investors for changes on how
the company is structured and run ever
since it was spun off from J&J just a
couple of years ago. Once again, Keny
shares up by more than 2.2%. Nora,
well, a couple decliners that I'm
keeping an eye on right now. We had
Waters, uh, that is a life sciences
company about $18 billion in market cap.
It fell for double-digit losses when we
ended at the close today after saying
that it'll merge with Beckton
Dickinson's biosciences and diagnostic
solutions business in a reverse Morris
Trust transaction that's valued at about
17.5 billion. We had Jeffre analyst
saying that they expect the stock to
trade down due to the deal size and
variables added to a clean replacement
cycle story. But if you look at the
stock on a year-to- date basis down
about 18%. I know it's Monday, but I did
want to talk about an alcohol company.
I'm looking at Constellation Brands, and
we're seeing shares that also fell at
the close today after President Trump
declared a 30% tariff for Mexico and the
EU. Uh, which of course we know these
are key markets for those drink makers.
So, tariffs are really the story here.
But, uh, this is a $28 billion company.
They own Medela, Corona, a lot of the
names that we know here. But, shares are
down about 26% this year. So, not great
news here for the brand. Maybe people
are going to healthier alternatives.
We'll see.
I like the fact you picked an alcohol
company because you really truly are
filling Carol Masters.
Have to live up to it the best I can.
Also, Fluence Energy, that's uh an
energy per uh this is an energy company
and we saw energy is the worst
performing sector in the S&P 500 today
and this was one of the names that was
in the red. Missou cut the stock to
neutral from outperform. They're also
pointing toward this tariff impact and
additionally the Republican tax and
spending bills effects on the clean
energy sector. The company's about$ 1.4
billion dollars in market cap, but I'm
looking at the year-to- date as well
down 50%. Not looking good.
All right, let's get a quick check on
yields. Continue to see a steepening of
the curve. Uh treasuries overall falling
for a third straight day. That's pushing
yields higher, but two interesting
dynamics are playing out. One is
obviously that you're seeing much
greater moves in yields on the longer
end of the curve to the upside. But on
the short end of the curve, take a look
at that. A one basis point move, one and
a half if you want to be uh particular
on that two-year yield. And that has
been the narrow range that we've
actually seen on the shorter end of the
curve now for quite some time. In fact,
the past three sessions, we basically
had one basis point, one basis point,
and then three basis points. And then if
you keep going out, it really doesn't
get much wider than that. And I think it
is kind of telling uh Tim and Nora this
idea uh that maybe you have a market at
least in the Treasury market with a lot
of folks right now on the sideline.
The Stock Movers Report from Bloomberg
Radio. Check back with us throughout the
day for the latest roundup of companies
making news on Wall Street. And for the
latest market moving headlines, listen
to Bloomberg Radio Live. Catch us on
YouTube, bloomberg.com, and on Apple
CarPlay and Android Auto with the
Bloomberg Business App.

cleanText:
[Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts, radio, news.
This is the closing bell on the Stock Movers report.
The company's making moves at the close of United States trading with Carol Masser, Tim Stenovec, Romaine Bostick, and Scarlet Fu.

All right, on the gainer side, a new all-time high for Fastenal.
The company reported earnings earlier today.
Shares 4% higher at the close.
The company reported net sales for the second quarter that were up 8.6% over the same period last year.
It did meet the average analyst estimate.
We had Daniel Florness on the show, the company's CEO.
He said that his industrial customers are starting to see business turnaround.
Here's what he said.
Quote, "The knife has stopped dropping."
What he was referring to is the trying to catch a falling knife over the last few years that really in the United States has been industrial production.
I did ask him and Norah asked him too about the impact of tariffs and he said they tried to move their supply chain back in 2018 during this first round and they were able to make some changes not necessarily bringing anything back to the United States, just not possible right now.
Uh too early to say for his customers though whether this new tariff regime will prompt them to move manufacturing back to the United States.
It's just a reminder of how long it takes to actually move your supply chain back to the United States.
They were talking about this back in 2017 and, you know, weren't able to to get very far.
Yeah.
I mean, do you remember the move back in 2017 and 2018 was to move everything out of China and like go to Vietnam or Indonesia or India?
Well, now it kind of doesn't matter where you are if you're not in the United States because all of those countries are getting tariffed as well.
Hey, did any of you guys see Superman over the weekend?
No.
Was it good?
I didn't see it either.
A lot of people did see it though.
We look at you when we see Superman.
I was going to say, wow, you guys, you guys are the best.
Uh Warner Brothers Discovery shares up more than 2%.
Uh this after the company did say uh that they brought in at least $115 million domestically.
It did take in $220 million worldwide.
This according to a statement from Warner Brothers, excuse me, $125 million in ticket sales in the United States.
So that did beat expectations of $115 million.
This is just the opening chapter in a 10-year plan dinner weave movies and TV shows based on DC comic book characters such as Batman and Wonder Woman.
Wouldn't they have done this before?
Yeah.
Okay.
All right.
I'm just
They've done this.
So, I mean, I don't know.
Do you think DC is going to get it right this time?
I mean, everyone's saying, "Okay, you had a decent box office domestically, though, don't look at the international numbers, Tim.
Was not as good."
But this idea that maybe they could finally build off this and and actually truly build up something that's comparable to the Marvel universe.
Look, I don't know what it takes to have a successful franchise.
No, I don't either, but I like but but we can we can look and see what you know what what the Marvel universe has done, right?
Peanut gallery speaks.
Yeah, exactly.
I think James Gunn knows a little more than we do when it comes to what makes a successful movie.
Uh and finally, I do want to talk about Shen View real quick.
Up they finished the day higher today by more than 2%.
It's the company behind Tylenol, Neutrogena, and Listerine, formerly the consumer healthcare division of J&J.
The company said that CEO Thiba Ming Mongol is going to leave the company as it continues to revamp.
The board director Kirk Perry will take over as interim CEO effective immediately.
They faced push from activist investors for changes on how the company is structured and run ever since it was spun off from J&J just a couple of years ago.
Once again, Keny shares up by more than 2.2%.
Nora, well, a couple decliners that I'm keeping an eye on right now.
We had Waters, uh, that is a life sciences company about $18 billion in market cap.
It fell for double-digit losses when we ended at the close today after saying that it'll merge with Becton Dickinson's Biosciences & Diagnostic Solutions business in a Reverse Morris Trust transaction that's valued at about 17.5 billion.
We had Jefferies analyst saying that they expect the stock to trade down due to the deal size and variables added to a clean replacement cycle story.
But if you look at the stock on a year-to- date basis down about 18%.
I know it's Monday, but I did want to talk about an alcohol company.
I'm looking at Constellation Brands, and we're seeing shares that also fell at the close today after President Trump declared a 30% tariff for Mexico and the EU.
Uh, which of course we know these are key markets for those drink makers.
So, tariffs are really the story here.
But, uh, this is a $28 billion company.
They own Medela, Corona, a lot of the names that we know here.
But, shares are down about 26% this year.
So, not great news here for the brand.
Maybe people are going to healthier alternatives.
We'll see.
I like the fact you picked an alcohol company because you really truly are filling Carol Masser.
Have to live up to it the best I can.
Also, Fluence Energy, that's uh an energy per uh this is an energy company and we saw energy is the worst performing sector in the S&P 500 today and this was one of the names that was in the red.
Missou cut the stock to neutral from outperform.
They're also pointing toward this tariff impact and additionally the Republican tax and spending bills effects on the clean energy sector.
The company's about $1.4 billion dollars in market cap, but I'm looking at the year-to- date as well down 50%.
Not looking good.
All right, let's get a quick check on yields.
Continue to see a steepening of the curve.
Uh treasuries overall falling for a third straight day.
That's pushing yields higher, but two interesting dynamics are playing out.
One is obviously that you're seeing much greater moves in yields on the longer end of the curve to the upside.
But on the short end of the curve, take a look at that.
A one basis point move, one and a half if you want to be uh particular on that two-year yield.
And that has been the narrow range that we've actually seen on the shorter end of the curve now for quite some time.
In fact, the past three sessions, we basically had one basis point, one basis point, and then three basis points.
And then if you keep going out, it really doesn't get much wider than that.
And I think it is kind of telling uh Tim and Nora this idea uh that maybe you have a market at least in the Treasury market with a lot of folks right now on the sideline.
The Stock Movers Report from Bloomberg Radio.
Check back with us throughout the day for the latest roundup of companies making news on Wall Street.
And for the latest market moving headlines, listen to Bloomberg Radio Live.
Catch us on YouTube, bloomberg.com, and on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business App.
